title: How to Make Spring Flower Yarn Art

steps.headline: Draw a flower shape onto a sheet of colored paper.
steps.description: You can do just about any type of flower you want. Buttercups and tulips are great choices, but you can do a simple 5-petal flower too. You can even get fancy and add a center, stem, and leaves to the flower. Use a pencil and draw lightly. This way, the mark will be less noticeable. Thick paper, such as cardstock, will work the best.

steps.headline: Apply some white school glue to your first petal.
steps.description: Draw a swirl of glue into the petal first, then blend it out with the tip. You can also paint the glue on with a brush instead, but make sure that you apply it thickly. Make sure that you fill the petal in completely; don't go outside the lines.

steps.headline: Coil your desired color of yarn into the glue.
steps.description: Start from the center, and work your way outward. Add more glue, a needed. When you reach the outer edge of the petal, cut the yarn, and press the end down. If you are doing a tulip, consider working in tear-drop shapes instead. Regular, medium-weight yarn will work the best for this.

steps.headline: Glue the yarn to the rest of the flower using the same technique.
steps.description: Work one petal at a time. When you get to the center, switch to yellow yarn. If your flower is already yellow, you can use orange, brown, or black for the center instead. Work one petal at a time, otherwise the glue will dry too fast.

steps.headline: Add a stem and leaves, if desired.
steps.description: Draw a line of glue going from the bottom of the flower down to the bottom edge of the paper. Press a strand of green yarn into the glue, then cut the excess off. If you added leaves, fill them in with more glue. Follow the shape of the leaves--they will likely be more almond-shaped than circle.

steps.headline: Allow the glue to dry.
steps.description: Once the glue dries, you can display your project!

steps.headline: Draw a flower outline on a sheet of white cardstock.
steps.description: Keep the shape simple, such as a tulip or a 5-petal flower. If you don't have any cardstock, you can use poster paper or even watercolor paper. Make the flower about the size of your hand. Consider cutting the paper down into a square shape. This will make it look nicer in the end. Don't draw the center or the stem of the flower.

steps.headline: Use a needle to punch holes on the line that you drew.
steps.description: Keep the holes close together, about ½-inch (1.27-centimeter) or finger-width apart. Make sure that they are spaced evenly. Put something soft under the paper, such as a piece of corrugated cardboard or a sheet of craft foam.

steps.headline: Thread a large needle with yarn, and tie a knot at the end.
steps.description: You can use any needle with a large opening, such as a darning needle, tapestry needle, or yarn needle. Use a bright, pretty color for the yarn. It can be solid colored or tie dye. Cut a piece of yarn that runs from your fingertip to your elbow. It will be easier to work with. You can use fine to medium-weight yarn for this.

steps.headline: Turn the paper over, then begin to sew the flower from the back.
steps.description: Flip the paper over first so that you can't see the lines that you drew any more. Poke the needle through the back of one hole and out the front. Pull on the yarn until the knot bumps up against the paper.

steps.headline: Cross the needle down through the opposite hole.
steps.description: You should now have a line of yarn going straight across your flower.

steps.headline: Continue sewing back and forth across the flower until you fill all the holes.
steps.description: Make some lines parallel to each other, and cross-cross other lines. As you continue to sew the flower, the flower will become more colorful. If you run out of yarn, knot and tape down the old piece to the back of the paper. Cut and knot a new piece, and continue sewing.

steps.headline: Knot and tape down the end of the thread on the back of the paper.
steps.description: Pull the needle down through the last hole so that it comes out of the back of the paper. Tie a knot into the yarn, then cut off the excess. Tape the tail end of the yarn down.

steps.headline: Glue a pompom or a large, plastic button to the center of the flower.
steps.description: You can use a regular pompom, or you can make your own. You can also use a large, 2- or 4-hole button. For an even fancier flower, you could use a large, sparkly rhinestone. Choose your desired item, then glue it down to the center of the flower. Hot glue or tacky glue will work the best for this.

steps.headline: Glue the flower to a larger, colored sheet of paper, if desired.
steps.description: Cut a sheet of colored paper that's 2 inches (5.08 centimeters) taller and 2 inches (5.08 centimeters) wider than your project. Coat the back of your project with glue, then press it down onto the center of the colored paper. You will have a colorful, 1-inch (2.54-centimeter) frame all around your project.

steps.headline: Draw a simple, 5-petal flower on a wooden board with a pencil.
steps.description: Leave ½ to 1 inch (1.27 to 2.54 centimeters) of space between the flower and the edges of the board. The board can be any size you want, but something around 10 by 5 inches (cc by 12.7 centimeters) would be ideal. Make sure that the board is at least ½-inch (1.27-centimeter) thick. A soft wood, like pine, will be easier to work with than others. If you want to get fancy, add a circle for the center of the 5-petal flower. You can also add a set of leaves as well.

steps.headline: Hammer nails halfway into the board, right over the lines that you draw.
steps.description: If you added a circle center, start with that first. Do the outline of the flower last. Use a hammer to pound the nails into the board. Keep them evenly spaces, about ½ to ¾ inch (1.27 to 1.91 centimeters) apart. Don't pound the nails all the way into the board. Pound them about halfway. Younger children may need help with this step.

steps.headline: Tie a piece of colored yarn to one of the nails on the outside of the flower.
steps.description: Choose a color that you think would look nice on a flower, such as red, pink, purple or blue. Use fine or medium-weight yarn.

steps.headline: Cross the yarn over to a nail on the opposite side of the flower.
steps.description: If you added a center to the flower, wrap the yarn around that instead. Keep crossing the yarn from nail to nail until the flower is filled. You don't have to cross the yarn to the opposite nail every time; you can cross it over to the third nail over (skipping one in between).

steps.headline: Weave the yarn around the nails to create the outline.
steps.description: Pull the yarn over and under through the nails until you are back where you started. If you want a thicker outline, go one more time around the flower: under and over this time.

steps.headline: Knot and cut the yarn.
steps.description: Once you are happy with your flower, wrap the yarn around the nail a few times, then tie it in a double knot. Snip off the excess yarn.

steps.headline: Do the center and leaves, if you added them.
steps.description: Use yellow for the center and green for the leaves. If you make your flower yellow, consider using orange, brown, or black yarn for the center. Remember to outline the center and leaves when you are done, and to knot and cut off the tails.

tyn: Green and yellow yarn (optional, for stem, leaves ,and center)
Wooden board, at least ½ inch (1.27 centimeters) thick
text: Making a Swirled Yarn Flower Draw a flower shape onto a sheet of colored paper. You can do just about any type of flower you want. Buttercups and tulips are great choices, but you can do a simple 5-petal flower too. You can even get fancy and add a center, stem, and leaves to the flower. Use a pencil and draw lightly. This way, the mark will be less noticeable. Thick paper, such as cardstock, will work the best. Apply some white school glue to your first petal. Draw a swirl of glue into the petal first, then blend it out with the tip. You can also paint the glue on with a brush instead, but make sure that you apply it thickly. Make sure that you fill the petal in completely; don't go outside the lines. Coil your desired color of yarn into the glue. Start from the center, and work your way outward. Add more glue, a needed. When you reach the outer edge of the petal, cut the yarn, and press the end down. If you are doing a tulip, consider working in tear-drop shapes instead. Regular, medium-weight yarn will work the best for this. Glue the yarn to the rest of the flower using the same technique. Work one petal at a time. When you get to the center, switch to yellow yarn. If your flower is already yellow, you can use orange, brown, or black for the center instead. Work one petal at a time, otherwise the glue will dry too fast. Add a stem and leaves, if desired. Draw a line of glue going from the bottom of the flower down to the bottom edge of the paper. Press a strand of green yarn into the glue, then cut the excess off. If you added leaves, fill them in with more glue. Follow the shape of the leaves--they will likely be more almond-shaped than circle. Allow the glue to dry. Once the glue dries, you can display your project! Making a Stitched Yarn Flower Draw a flower outline on a sheet of white cardstock. Keep the shape simple, such as a tulip or a 5-petal flower. If you don't have any cardstock, you can use poster paper or even watercolor paper. Make the flower about the size of your hand. Consider cutting the paper down into a square shape. This will make it look nicer in the end. Don't draw the center or the stem of the flower. Use a needle to punch holes on the line that you drew. Keep the holes close together, about ½-inch (1.27-centimeter) or finger-width apart. Make sure that they are spaced evenly. Put something soft under the paper, such as a piece of corrugated cardboard or a sheet of craft foam. Thread a large needle with yarn, and tie a knot at the end. You can use any needle with a large opening, such as a darning needle, tapestry needle, or yarn needle. Use a bright, pretty color for the yarn. It can be solid colored or tie dye. Cut a piece of yarn that runs from your fingertip to your elbow. It will be easier to work with. You can use fine to medium-weight yarn for this. Turn the paper over, then begin to sew the flower from the back. Flip the paper over first so that you can't see the lines that you drew any more. Poke the needle through the back of one hole and out the front. Pull on the yarn until the knot bumps up against the paper. Cross the needle down through the opposite hole. You should now have a line of yarn going straight across your flower. Continue sewing back and forth across the flower until you fill all the holes. Make some lines parallel to each other, and cross-cross other lines. As you continue to sew the flower, the flower will become more colorful. If you run out of yarn, knot and tape down the old piece to the back of the paper. Cut and knot a new piece, and continue sewing. Knot and tape down the end of the thread on the back of the paper. Pull the needle down through the last hole so that it comes out of the back of the paper. Tie a knot into the yarn, then cut off the excess. Tape the tail end of the yarn down. Glue a pompom or a large, plastic button to the center of the flower. You can use a regular pompom, or you can make your own. You can also use a large, 2- or 4-hole button. For an even fancier flower, you could use a large, sparkly rhinestone. Choose your desired item, then glue it down to the center of the flower. Hot glue or tacky glue will work the best for this. Glue the flower to a larger, colored sheet of paper, if desired. Cut a sheet of colored paper that's 2 inches (5.08 centimeters) taller and 2 inches (5.08 centimeters) wider than your project. Coat the back of your project with glue, then press it down onto the center of the colored paper. You will have a colorful, 1-inch (2.54-centimeter) frame all around your project. Making Nail Flower Art Draw a simple, 5-petal flower on a wooden board with a pencil. Leave ½ to 1 inch (1.27 to 2.54 centimeters) of space between the flower and the edges of the board. The board can be any size you want, but something around 10 by 5 inches (cc by 12.7 centimeters) would be ideal. Make sure that the board is at least ½-inch (1.27-centimeter) thick. A soft wood, like pine, will be easier to work with than others. If you want to get fancy, add a circle for the center of the 5-petal flower. You can also add a set of leaves as well. Hammer nails halfway into the board, right over the lines that you draw. If you added a circle center, start with that first. Do the outline of the flower last. Use a hammer to pound the nails into the board. Keep them evenly spaces, about ½ to ¾ inch (1.27 to 1.91 centimeters) apart. Don't pound the nails all the way into the board. Pound them about halfway. Younger children may need help with this step. Tie a piece of colored yarn to one of the nails on the outside of the flower. Choose a color that you think would look nice on a flower, such as red, pink, purple or blue. Use fine or medium-weight yarn. Cross the yarn over to a nail on the opposite side of the flower. If you added a center to the flower, wrap the yarn around that instead. Keep crossing the yarn from nail to nail until the flower is filled. You don't have to cross the yarn to the opposite nail every time; you can cross it over to the third nail over (skipping one in between). Weave the yarn around the nails to create the outline. Pull the yarn over and under through the nails until you are back where you started. If you want a thicker outline, go one more time around the flower: under and over this time. Knot and cut the yarn. Once you are happy with your flower, wrap the yarn around the nail a few times, then tie it in a double knot. Snip off the excess yarn. Do the center and leaves, if you added them. Use yellow for the center and green for the leaves. If you make your flower yellow, consider using orange, brown, or black yarn for the center. Remember to outline the center and leaves when you are done, and to knot and cut off the tails.
sentences: Making a Swirled Yarn Flower Draw a flower shape onto a sheet of colored paper.
You can do just about any type of flower you want.
Buttercups and tulips are great choices, but you can do a simple 5-petal flower too.
You can even get fancy and add a center, stem, and leaves to the flower.
Use a pencil and draw lightly.
This way, the mark will be less noticeable.
Thick paper, such as cardstock, will work the best.
Apply some white school glue to your first petal.
Draw a swirl of glue into the petal first, then blend it out with the tip.
You can also paint the glue on with a brush instead, but make sure that you apply it thickly.
Make sure that you fill the petal in completely; don't go outside the lines.
Coil your desired color of yarn into the glue.
Start from the center, and work your way outward.
Add more glue, a needed.
When you reach the outer edge of the petal, cut the yarn, and press the end down.
If you are doing a tulip, consider working in tear-drop shapes instead.
Regular, medium-weight yarn will work the best for this.
Glue the yarn to the rest of the flower using the same technique.
Work one petal at a time.
When you get to the center, switch to yellow yarn.
If your flower is already yellow, you can use orange, brown, or black for the center instead.
Work one petal at a time, otherwise the glue will dry too fast.
Add a stem and leaves, if desired.
Draw a line of glue going from the bottom of the flower down to the bottom edge of the paper.
Press a strand of green yarn into the glue, then cut the excess off.
If you added leaves, fill them in with more glue.
Follow the shape of the leaves--they will likely be more almond-shaped than circle.
Allow the glue to dry.
Once the glue dries, you can display your project!
Making a Stitched Yarn Flower Draw a flower outline on a sheet of white cardstock.
Keep the shape simple, such as a tulip or a 5-petal flower.
If you don't have any cardstock, you can use poster paper or even watercolor paper.
Make the flower about the size of your hand.
Consider cutting the paper down into a square shape.
This will make it look nicer in the end.
Don't draw the center or the stem of the flower.
Use a needle to punch holes on the line that you drew.
Keep the holes close together, about ½-inch (1.27-centimeter) or finger-width apart.
Make sure that they are spaced evenly.
Put something soft under the paper, such as a piece of corrugated cardboard or a sheet of craft foam.
Thread a large needle with yarn, and tie a knot at the end.
You can use any needle with a large opening, such as a darning needle, tapestry needle, or yarn needle.
Use a bright, pretty color for the yarn.
It can be solid colored or tie dye.
Cut a piece of yarn that runs from your fingertip to your elbow.
It will be easier to work with.
You can use fine to medium-weight yarn for this.
Turn the paper over, then begin to sew the flower from the back.
Flip the paper over first so that you can't see the lines that you drew any more.
Poke the needle through the back of one hole and out the front.
Pull on the yarn until the knot bumps up against the paper.
Cross the needle down through the opposite hole.
You should now have a line of yarn going straight across your flower.
Continue sewing back and forth across the flower until you fill all the holes.
Make some lines parallel to each other, and cross-cross other lines.
As you continue to sew the flower, the flower will become more colorful.
If you run out of yarn, knot and tape down the old piece to the back of the paper.
Cut and knot a new piece, and continue sewing.
Knot and tape down the end of the thread on the back of the paper.
Pull the needle down through the last hole so that it comes out of the back of the paper.
Tie a knot into the yarn, then cut off the excess.
Tape the tail end of the yarn down.
Glue a pompom or a large, plastic button to the center of the flower.
You can use a regular pompom, or you can make your own.
You can also use a large, 2- or 4-hole button.
For an even fancier flower, you could use a large, sparkly rhinestone.
Choose your desired item, then glue it down to the center of the flower.
Hot glue or tacky glue will work the best for this.
Glue the flower to a larger, colored sheet of paper, if desired.
Cut a sheet of colored paper that's 2 inches (5.08 centimeters) taller and 2 inches (5.08 centimeters) wider than your project.
Coat the back of your project with glue, then press it down onto the center of the colored paper.
You will have a colorful, 1-inch (2.54-centimeter) frame all around your project.
Making Nail Flower Art Draw a simple, 5-petal flower on a wooden board with a pencil.
Leave ½ to 1 inch (1.27 to 2.54 centimeters) of space between the flower and the edges of the board.
The board can be any size you want, but something around 10 by 5 inches (cc by 12.7 centimeters) would be ideal.
Make sure that the board is at least ½-inch (1.27-centimeter) thick.
A soft wood, like pine, will be easier to work with than others.
If you want to get fancy, add a circle for the center of the 5-petal flower.
You can also add a set of leaves as well.
Hammer nails halfway into the board, right over the lines that you draw.
If you added a circle center, start with that first.
Do the outline of the flower last.
Use a hammer to pound the nails into the board.
Keep them evenly spaces, about ½ to ¾ inch (1.27 to 1.91 centimeters) apart.
Don't pound the nails all the way into the board.
Pound them about halfway.
Younger children may need help with this step.
Tie a piece of colored yarn to one of the nails on the outside of the flower.
Choose a color that you think would look nice on a flower, such as red, pink, purple or blue.
Use fine or medium-weight yarn.
Cross the yarn over to a nail on the opposite side of the flower.
If you added a center to the flower, wrap the yarn around that instead.
Keep crossing the yarn from nail to nail until the flower is filled.
You don't have to cross the yarn to the opposite nail every time; you can cross it over to the third nail over (skipping one in between).
Weave the yarn around the nails to create the outline.
Pull the yarn over and under through the nails until you are back where you started.
If you want a thicker outline, go one more time around the flower: under and over this time.
Knot and cut the yarn.
Once you are happy with your flower, wrap the yarn around the nail a few times, then tie it in a double knot.
Snip off the excess yarn.
Do the center and leaves, if you added them.
Use yellow for the center and green for the leaves.
If you make your flower yellow, consider using orange, brown, or black yarn for the center.
Remember to outline the center and leaves when you are done, and to knot and cut off the tails.
